PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences and no other. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer all the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Septimus Robert Graham
2. Your address: Estherville, Saskatchewan
3. Date: March 1947
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Northumberland England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: James Common
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): January 1914
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates and reasons:
   - Ottawa, Ontario, 1891-1901
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - To come with my family to work and they had a large family of seven
   - They came up to take up farming
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)
SASKATCHEWAN ADVENTURES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Septimus Robert Common
2. Year address: Estevan, Saskatchewan
3. Date:
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Northumberland England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: James Common
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 1891
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: England, Ontario, Canada
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," I was in my twenties)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To travel to Canada with my family to work and they heard a large family of ours had come up to take up farming.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other peoples' hearing about it? Railroad or government information): Reading newspapers
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They thought it was alright.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   With the family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   By train from Ottawa to Wapella then by sleigh to a farm.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   We left Wapella one of my brothers and I walked the 30 miles driving 3 cows we brought with us, we arrived at a squatter's shack near our farm and stayed there in my a fine come and burnt everything allow goods lumber we bought, we lost anything some neighbors came and helped us put up a log shack in a hurry.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   I was put out to a farmer for to work for my board and clothes for 1 year, this farmer put me in the field to plow with a team of oxen I had never drawn anything before.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Section 2 Township 19 Range 38 west of the meridian.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   3 yrs at Melville 1908 to 1910 I worked for the railroad.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   In England I went to school and was messenger boy in a store. In Ottawa I handled cows. Back I farmed.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   *Women wrote the mother and sisters did.*

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
    *Mildred Noble Cockburn*
    *Hazelcliff 1904, apr. 4th*

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
    *A married brother came common*

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
    *James Conner came in 1903 and settled on sec. 24 Township 19 range 38 W.M.*

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
    *The first 12 years we hauled our grain 3 miles by oxen no roads just across the prairie the grain was 40¢ for no 1 hard wheat, dairy butter was packed in tubs we got 13¢ a lb., eggs 8¢ a dozen we had to haul them too and in summer it was hard keeping the butter cool in winter it was impossible.*

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    *We used to haul our grain by oxen 3 miles twice a week, all winter every winter for a number of years,*
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We used to have our own ox team

Every winter for a number of years,
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   The first car was used by a neighbor in 1912.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Wapella 30 miles away

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We traded there till the railroad came up and a town called Hazelcliff started up 3 miles from our place.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About 1910

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   We dealt with Eaton's in Toronto as soon as we came up. Mostly clothing and beddings.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1912, started by the Hazelcliff Rural Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   We intended to stay permanently.
25. When was the first car used in the community? The first car was used by a neighbor in 1912.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, then did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Inabella 30 miles away

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns, appearance of better means of travel, etc.)

The railroad came up and a store called Osgoodville opened up 3 miles from our house.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Almost once a week.

30. Whom (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Before 1910

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in this proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

We dealt with Eaton's in Toronto as soon as we came up. Winter clothing and clothing

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1912

33. When you came to Saskatoon the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? We wanted to stay forever.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Mr. Delmage the 1st postmaster named Kingscliff on account of the hills surrounding it. Our school district was named by my mother she came from a place in England called Clynn, but there was another place called that. No way had to put king in front making it Kingscliff. The 1st school was started in 1908 then we built a larger school in 1921 also a teacherage alongside.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? If so, where did they move?

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? If so, where did they move?

37. If you or any of your family were elected to office, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.
